sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &app; (grecord) is a simple GNOME-enabled sound recorder. &app; allows you to record sounds using your sound hardware, and save them to a wave (.WAV) file.

To run &app; select
Multimedia Sound Recorder
from the Main Menu, or type gnome-sound-recorder on the command line.
&app; is included in the gnome-media package, which is part of the GNOME desktop environment. This document describes version &version; of &app;.

listitem.para: New — Start a new recording session.
Play — Play back the current recording.
Stop — Stop current record or playback operation.
Record — Begin recording to the current session.

sect1.title: The GNOME Sound Recorder Preferences
sect1.para: Preferences may be viewed and changed by selecting Preferences from the Settings.

listitem.para: The Recording timeout option specifies the maximum length (in minutes) of a recording (when used in conjunction with the Stop recording on timeout option.) The Popup save dialog when recording is finished option causes the Save sound file dialog to appear when the recording has finished (allowing the new recording to be saved immediately.)

The Popup warning message if size... option causes a warning message to appear if the current recording has grown past the specified size. The Stop recording if size... option causes the recording to stop if the current recording grows past the specified size.
The Repeat the sound option causes playback to repeat after reaching the end of the recording. Playback may repeat a given number of times, or until the Stop button is pressed (i.e. Forever.)

The "Path to sox" option allows the user to select the location of the sox application (used to play back the sound recordings.) This can usually be determined from the command line by typing which sox. The "Temporary directory" option allows the user to specify the directory in which to store files as they are being recorded.
These options collectively allow the user to determine the quality and file size of the sound recordings.

The "Audio format" option allows the user to select the size (in bits) of each sample. The "Sample rate" option allows the user to select the number of samples per second. The "Mono/Stereo" option allows the user to specify the number of audio channels to record (1 or 2.)

"Show time" displays the current position (in minutes and seconds) in the recording. "Show sound information" displays information related to the file type and sound quality of the current recording (as specified in hte Sound preferences.)

sect1.title: Known Bugs and Limitations
sect1.para: No known bugs at this time.

sect1.title: About &app;
sect1.para: Gnome Sound Recorderr was written by Andreas Hyden (a.hyden@cyberpoint.se.) To find more information about Gnome Sound Recorder, please visit the Gnome Sound Recorder page. Please send all comments, suggestions, and bug reports to the GNOME bug tracking database. (Instructions for submitting bug reports can be found on-line.) If you are using GNOME 1.1 or later, you can also use Bug Report Tool (bug-buddy), available in the Utilities submenu of Main Menu, for submitting bug reports.

This manual was written by Michael Froh (msfroh@uwaterloo.ca). Please send all comments and suggestions regarding this manual to the
GNOME Documentation Project by sending an email to docs@gnome.org. You can also add your comments online by using the GNOME Documentation Status Table.
